subject: Education
subcategory: Great Teachers Who Changed the World
title: Janusz Korczak: The Teacher Who Walked Into Death
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Janusz Korczak: The Teacher Who Walked Into Death.

hook.text: Janusz Korczak ran an orphanage in the Warsaw Ghetto. When the Nazis came for his children, he refused to save himself

buildup.text: Korczak believed children had rights decades before the UN declared them. His orphanage was a child-run democracy.

discovery.text: Children in his orphanage ran their own court, newspaper, and parliament. He treated them as citizens, not subjects.

twist.text: Offered escape multiple times, Korczak refused to abandon his 192 children. He marched with them to Treblinka in August

climax.text: Korczak's sacrifice embodied his teaching: children deserve unconditional respect, care, and love ‚Äî even unto death.

punchline.text: He could have saved himself. He chose to walk into death with his children.

quiz.question: What was Korczak's revolutionary approach to education?
options: Treating children as citizens with rights in a child-run democracy
